If it's worth testing, then it may not be an implementation detail, and
per=
haps either should be part of the public interface or part of the public
in=
terface of another class.

Don't let me misrepresent myself: I agree with w=
hat you're writing; however
it usually points to a code smell, the most com=
mon of which is "one class
buried in another one". Your class has seven pri=
vate methods to help it do
its work, which perhaps points to those seven me=
thods belonging on a new
class with which the existing class should collabo=
rate. Now you have a new
public interface to test and life is simpler.

If =
there's more, let's take it offline; otherwise, best of luck.

Yes. Don't test protected and =
 package-protected methods.

A quote from the XP discussion group.
(http://=
208.48.218.9/group/extremeprogramming/message/13213)

"I  actually do think=
 that it is cut and dried. Public members have a
behavior  that is expected=
 of them by their clients. Tests can be used to
define that  behavior and d=
emonstrate that a particular method exhibits it.
Private  methods are, by d=
efinition, implementation details. Their behavior
can vary  freely so long =
as the public methods don't break. Put another
way:
if every  public method=
 has been proven to behave correctly then the class
has been  proven to be =
bug free. Therefore, there is never a need to test
the private  members of =
a class."

So can you avoid testing them? If so, then don't;  if not, then =
you can't
have it both ways: either the tests are in the class  (to test pr=
ivate
methods),
in the package (to test protected/package  methods) or you =
can't test those
methods. There's no magic  here...

Good luck,
